user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_FileSysStatVolume:
```c
int32 OS_FileSysStatVolume(const char *name, OS_statvfs_t *statbuf)
{
    int32             return_code;
    OS_object_token_t token;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_PATHNAME(name);
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(statbuf);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, OS_FileSys_FindVirtMountPoint,
                                         (void *)name, &token);

    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_FileSysStatVolume_Impl(&token, statbuf);

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_FileSysStatVolume:
#define OS_CHECK_PATHNAME(str) OS_CHECK_STRING(str,OS_MAX_PATH_LEN,OS_FS_ERR_PATH_TOO_LONG)
...
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, OS_ObjectMatchFunc_t MatchFunc, void *arg,
                             OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdFindNextMatch(MatchFunc, arg, token);

    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "lock_mode" parameter.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }
    else
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
bool OS_FileSys_FindVirtMountPoint(void *ref, const OS_object_token_t *token, const OS_common_record_t *obj)
{
    OS_filesys_internal_record_t *filesys;
    const char *                  target = (const char *)ref;
    size_t                        mplen;

    filesys = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_filesys_table, *token);

    if ((filesys->flags & OS_FILESYS_FLAG_IS_MOUNTED_VIRTUAL) == 0)
    {
        return false;
    }

    mplen = OS_strnlen(filesys->virtual_mountpt, sizeof(filesys->virtual_mountpt));

    /*
     * The virtual_mountpt member should be a substring of the search target.
     * If this matches a basic substring check then it may be match
     */
    if (mplen == 0 || mplen >= sizeof(filesys->virtual_mountpt) ||
        strncmp(target, filesys->virtual_mountpt, mplen) != 0)
    {
        /* not a substring, so not a match */
        return false;
    }

    /*
     * Confirm that the substring ends at either a directory separator
     * or the end of string  (so exact mount points also match).
     *
     * For instance consider a virtual_mountpt of /mnt/abc and searching
     * for target=/mnt/abcd - this should return false in that case.
     */
    return (target[mplen] == '/' || target[mplen] == 0);
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
...
#define OS_INVALID_POINTER (-2)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I flagged all macro uses and functions that could introduce non-returning behavior or multiple transaction/return paths which might render other code unreachable: the two OS_CHECK_* macros (and the OS_CHECK_PATHNAME definition) because they expand to checks that invoke BUGCHECK or other error handling whose return behavior is not shown; the call to OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch and its implementation because it performs transaction begin/find/convert/cancel with multiple return branches; the conditional block in OS_FileSysStatVolume that uses the token (OS_FileSysStatVolume_Impl and OS_ObjectIdRelease) since token lifecycle depends on the earlier call's outcome; OS_FileSys_FindVirtMountPoint because it contains several early returns and a final return expression that should be validated for reachability and bounds assumptions; and OS_ObjectIdRelease since it wraps the transaction finish. These fragments should be investigated for possible non-returning paths or constant conditions that would make subsequent statements unreachable. Other code fragments were not marked because they are simple, locally consistent constructs without obvious unconditional jumps or constant-false/constant-true conditions in the provided snippets (for example the final "return return_code;" in OS_FileSysStatVolume and the OS_SUCCESS/OS_INVALID_POINTER constant definitions). If further macro/function definitions (for example BUGCHECK or OS_CHECK_STRING) are provided and show non-returning behavior or constant conditions, additional fragments should be re-evaluated.
